statement:
If $ABCD$ is a cyclic quadrilateral, then the product of the two
diagonals is equal to the sum of the products of opposite sides.

![image](ptolemy)

$$AC\cdot BD = AB\cdot CD + AD \cdot BC.$$

When the quadrilateral is not cyclic we have the following inequality
$$AB\cdot CD+BC\cdot AD>AC\cdot BD$$

An interesting particular case is when both $AC$ and $BD$ are diameters,
since we get another proof of Pythagoras’ theorem.
